Thanks Colin. I'm continuing to look into it and I'll definitely try that.
=

I've also noticed that the elitism is all over the board. We have it set t=
o
0.2 with a population of 100, so I'm expecting it to be 20 individuals.
H=
owever, it looks like it never gets to 20 in a generation (usually around
1=
5-18), and it can even go as low as 1 individual at times. The elitism
code=
 in SN2 looks fairly sophisticated, so I wasn't sure if this was an
intende=
d default behavior or not. If it is, is there some way to reduce the
varian=
ce so that we can always have 20 (maybe +/- 2) survivors in the
population?=


Wesley

On Sun, Dec 18, 2011 at 7:16 PM, Colin Green <colin.green1@gmail.=
com> wrote:

> **
>
>
> Hi Wesley,
>
> That fitness dip is not something I =
have observed or have been made
> aware of by others. Nothing comes immedia=
tely to mind but I'll have a
> think. Maybe try disabling the complexity re=
gulation (phased pruning)
> - there might be some weird dynamic/feedback in=
teraction going on,
> maybe specific to your problem domain.
>
> Colin.
>  =

>

--20cf3079b88ce0445c04b467c8b3

Thanks Colin. I'm continuing to look into it and I'll definitely tr=
y that.<div><br></div><div>I've also noticed that the elitism is all ov=
er the board. We have it set to 0.2 with a population of 100, so I'm ex=
pecting it to be 20 individuals. However, it looks like it never gets to 20=
 in a generation (usually around 15-18), and it can even go as low as 1 ind=
ividual at times. The elitism code in SN2 looks fairly sophisticated, so I =
wasn't sure if this was an intended default behavior or not. If it is, =
is there some way to reduce the variance so that we can always have 20 (may=
be +/- 2) survivors in the population?</div>
